captions.text: I was born and raised in North Korea.
Although my family constantly struggled against poverty,
I was always loved and cared for first,
because I was the only son
and the youngest of two in the family.
But then the great famine began in 1994.
I was four years old.
My sister and I would go searching for firewood
starting at 5 in the morning
and come back after midnight.
I would wander the streets searching for food,
and I remember seeing a small child
tied to a mother's back eating chips,
and wanting to steal them from him.
Hunger is humiliation. Hunger is hopelessness.
For a hungry child, politics and freedom
are not even thought of.
On my ninth birthday, my parents
couldn't give me any food to eat.
But even as a child, I could feel the heaviness
in their hearts.
Over a million North Koreans died of starvation in that time,
and in 2003, when I was 13 years old,
my father became one of them.
I saw my father wither away and die.
In the same year, my mother disappeared one day,
and then my sister told me
that she was going to China to earn money,
but that she would return with money and food soon.
Since we had never been separated,
and I thought we would be together forever,
I didn't even give her a hug when she left.
It was the biggest mistake I have ever made in my life.
But again, I didn't know
it was going to be a long goodbye.
I have not seen my mom or my sister since then.
Suddenly, I became an orphan and homeless.
My daily life became very hard,
but very simple.
My goal was to find a dusty piece of bread in the trash.
But that is no way to survive.
I started to realize, begging would not be the solution.
So I started to steal from food carts in illegal markets.
Sometimes, I found small jobs
in exchange for food.
Once, I even spent two months in the winter
working in a coal mine,
33 meters underground without any protection
for up to 16 hours a day.
I was not uncommon.
Many other orphans survived this way, or worse.
When I could not fall asleep from bitter cold
or hunger pains,
I hoped that, the next morning,
my sister would come back to wake me up
with my favorite food.
That hope kept me alive.
I don't mean big, grand hope.
I mean the kind of hope that made me believe
that the next trash can had bread,
even though it usually didn't.
But if I didn't believe it, I wouldn't even try,
and then I would die.
Hope kept me alive.
Every day, I told myself,
no matter how hard things got,
still I must live.
After three years of waiting for my sister's return,
I decided to go to China to look for her myself.
I realized
I couldn't survive much longer this way.
I knew the journey would be risky,
but I would be risking my life either way.
I could die of starvation like my father in North Korea,
or at least I could try for a better life
by escaping to China.
I had learned that many people tried to cross
the border to China in the nighttime to avoid being seen.
North Korean border guards often shoot and kill people
trying to cross the border without permission.
Chinese soldiers will catch
and send back North Koreans,
where they face severe punishment.
I decided to cross during the day,
first because I was still a kid and scared of the dark,
second because I knew I was already taking a risk,
and since not many people tried to cross during the day,
I thought I might be able to cross
without being seen by anyone.
I made it to China on February 15, 2006.
I was 16 years old.
I thought things in China would be easier,
since there was more food.
I thought more people would help me.
But it was harder than living in North Korea,
because I was not free.
I was always worried about being caught
and sent back.
By a miracle, some months later,
I met someone who was running
an underground shelter for North Koreans,
and was allowed to live there
and eat regular meals for the first time in many years.
Later that year, an activist helped me escape China
and go to the United States as a refugee.
I went to America without knowing a word of English,
yet my social worker told me that I had to go to high school.
Even in North Korea, I was an F student.
(Laughter)
And I barely finished elementary school.
And I remember I fought in school more than once a day.
Textbooks and the library were not my playground.
My father tried very hard to motivate me into studying,
but it didn't work.
At one point, my father gave up on me.
He said, "You're not my son anymore."
I was only 11 or 12, but it hurt me deeply.
But nevertheless, my level of motivation
still didn't change before he died.
So in America, it was kind of ridiculous
that they said I should go to high school.
I didn't even go to middle school.
I decided to go, just because they told me to,
without trying much.
But one day, I came home and my foster mother
had made chicken wings for dinner.
And during dinner, I wanted to have one more wing,
but I realized there were not enough for everyone,
so I decided against it.
When I looked down at my plate,
I saw the last chicken wing, that my foster father had given me his.
I was so happy.
I looked at him sitting next to me.
He just looked back at me very warmly,
but said no words.
Suddenly I remembered my biological father.
My foster father's small act of love
reminded me of my father,
who would love to share his food with me
when he was hungry, even if he was starving.
I felt so suffocated that I had so much food in America,
yet my father died of starvation.
My only wish that night was to cook a meal for him,
and that night I also thought of what else I could do
to honor him.
And my answer was to promise to myself
that I would study hard and get the best education
in America to honor his sacrifice.
I took school seriously,
and for the first time ever in my life,
I received an academic award for excellence,
and made dean's list from the first semester in high school.
(Applause)
That chicken wing changed my life.
(Laughter)
Hope is personal. Hope is something
that no one can give to you.
You have to choose to believe in hope.
You have to make it yourself.
In North Korea, I made it myself.
Hope brought me to America.
But in America, I didn't know what to do,
because I had this overwhelming freedom.
My foster father at that dinner gave me a direction,
and he motivated me and gave me a purpose
to live in America.
I did not come here by myself.
I had hope, but hope by itself is not enough.
Many people helped me along the way to get here.
North Koreans are fighting hard to survive.
They have to force themselves to survive,
have hope to survive,
but they cannot make it without help.
This is my message to you.
Have hope for yourself,
but also help each other.
Life can be hard for everyone, wherever you live.
My foster father didn't intend to change my life.
In the same way, you may also change someone's life
with even the smallest act of love.
A piece of bread can satisfy your hunger,
and having the hope will bring you bread
to keep you alive.
But I confidently believe that
your act of love and caring
can also save another Joseph's life
and change thousands of other Josephs
who are still having hope to survive.
Thank you.
(Applause)
Adrian Hong: Joseph, thank you for sharing
that very personal and special story with us.
I know you haven't seen your sister for, you said,
it was almost exactly a decade,
and in the off chance that she may be able to see this,
we wanted to give you an opportunity
to send her a message.
Joseph Kim: In Korean?
AH: You can do English, then Korean as well.
(Laughter)
JK: Okay, I'm not going to make it any longer in Korean
because I don't think I can make it
without tearing up.
Nuna, it has been already 10 years
that I haven't seen you.
I just wanted to say
that I miss you, and I love you,
and please come back to me and stay alive.
And I -- oh, gosh.
I still haven't given up my hope to see you.
I will live my life happily
and study hard
until I see you,
and I promise I will not cry again.
(Laughter)
Yes, I'm just looking forward to seeing you,
and if you can't find me,
I will also look for you,
and I hope to see you one day.
And can I also make a small message to my mom?
AH: Sure, please.
JK: I haven't spent much time with you,
but I know that you still love me,
and you probably still pray for me
and think about me.
I just wanted to say thank you
for letting me be in this world.
Thank you.
(Applause)

title: Joseph Kim: The family I lost in North Korea. And the family I gained.

comments.text:
As a Korean living on the south side, personally i don't want Korea to 
reunite for very selfish reasons like for our economy, education level and 
all the luxuries us South Koreans regard as the norms of living like a 
human being. But after seeing this lecture and all your heart aching 
comments, i reallu think we have to do something to hasten our unition. 
Even if it will bring up the 3rd world war, (and i really mean this 
literally. If Korea reunite, Russia and/or China might go on a war with the 
US, or vice versa) we WILL do our very best to fix this tear. So please 
China Russia Japan America and whoever are capable of affecting our 
unification process, help us. Donate us your words of approval, help us 
South and North Koreans to persuade both of the governments to end our 50 
year old war situation( p.s. we technically are still at war) and HELP US 
MAKE SOME WORLD PEACE. ﻿

comments.author: xyndey

comments.text:
I couldn't help tearing up when he started speaking to his sister. I can't 
imagine what it's like to be in that situation... Terrible. My great 
grandfather was an important congressman of South Korea, one of the 
country's first. He was a freedom-fighter before that, during the Japanese 
annexation of Korea. After Korea won its independence, split, and entered 
into civil war, my great grandfather was kidnapped to North Korea by North 
Korean spies, where he was probably tortured for information and executed. 
When I think about all that he's done to keep Korea (or at least a part of 
it) free, and when I think about how lucky my family and I are because of 
his sacrifices - lucky enough to become free American citizens - and when I 
think about how millions of others in North Korea aren't so lucky... god, 
it makes me so emotional. People like Joseph Kim and Hyeonseo Lee, and many 
others who have escaped, are so brave and strong. I hope more North Koreans 
can get out of that evil country and finally LIVE as human beings.﻿
comments.author: Rin la Harlequin

comments.author: Rin la Harlequin

comments.text:
+Rin la Harlequin While reading your comments and replies by the youtubers. 
It's like I'm having a history class LOL
comments.author: akosi sheilalat

comments.text:
+StephenB Thank you for your kind words. The South Korean government 
acknowledges his sacrifices in the form of official documents, plaques, and 
benefits to his son, my grandfather. Though my great grandfather is not as 
well known as Kim Gu, one of his friends and a fellow freedom fighter, my 
family and those who know him respect his memory and legacy. I'm just so 
happy to see how far Korea has come! :) Hopefully North Korea will someday 
enjoy the same freedoms the Southerners have experienced.
comments.author: Rin la Harlequin

comments.text:
+Rin la Harlequin Thank you for sharing! I wish your grandfather could see 
what he did for South Korea and know that he helped make it the great 
country it is today.

+Peter Bloom You are sad. (But I bet you already knew that.) What is the 
point/purpose of arguing with someone about their family history? Are you 
trying to point out that South Korea did bad things? Yes, there were some 
terrible things that happened while the South was stabilizing. However, 
they acknowledge and are deeply sorry for those things. The North on the 
other hand, has done so much worse for such a long time, and yet, they deny 
they are doing anything wrong. The North Korean government lies more than 
you start things in the YouTube comment section.

If you have actual evidence for your claim about the US's relationship with 
Korean freedom fighters, I would love for you to share it. Otherwise, your 
story sounds like a shit piece of work from North Korean sympathizers.
comments.author: StephenB

comments.text:
You're not answering my question first. What gives you the idea that I 
scripted my family's history, and what would my incentive be to lie to a 
bunch of strangers on the Internet? I've noticed that all over the video 
comments, you've been leaving accusations that these North Korean refugees 
are all scripting their testimonies.

Now I've heard rumors that some so-called refugees were not actually North 
Korean defectors, but in fact part Chinese, or whatever. Perhaps their 
motivations to lie were to gain public sympathy, or "donations." People 
like that are scammers, I do not deny that. But the few do not constitute 
the whole, the whole being the many North Korean defectors who have gone 
through hell and back, with nothing but bravery and desperation to be free 
human beings. Some, like Joseph, were motivated to pursue higher education 
despite their difficulties, including language skills.

Are their testimonies scripted? Perhaps, in the sense that their original 
words probably are not 100% grammatically correct, and were thus edited. 
But to accuse all of them of having fabricated everything is just 
insensitive, and it spits upon those who have suffered far more than we, or 
many others, probably have.

Now, to answer your question, I do know who the freedom fighters allied 
with: the Chinese. Of course it makes perfect sense why the US would 
dislike their alliance since America was itching to contain communism. I 
don't necessarily understand why you would ask me this and how it somehow 
proves that my great grandfather's story is fake. All you're doing is 
hurling trivia at me, hoping that I'll make a mistake that might prove your 
point, but it doesn't.

Anyway, I don't wish to lead a pointless debate into a pointless fight on 
the Internet. I can't force you to believe me, so believe what you will. 
I'll just assume that you had a good reason to question me and the other 
defectors since you don't sound like an idiot. Happy Holidays.
comments.author: Rin la Harlequin

comments.text:
My story sounds scripted? Wow. That's interesting considering how it was 
actually true. I don't have an incentive to make things up about my 
family's history. And I don't understand why you feel the need to tell me 
that I'm making this up. What do you gain from this exactly?

Japan annexed Korea and, yes, they imposed their will upon Korea and thus 
installed their government there. Just because Japan controlled the Korean 
peninsula for some time doesn't make my great grandfather's efforts any 
less true or valid. The Japanese were kicked out, civil war erupted, 
America tugged on the southern end of the peninsula to contain communism. 
The South Korean government tried to establish a stronger political 
footing. My great grandfather was not a fan of the Japanese invaders, but 
he was also not a fan of Northern Communists trying to impose their will on 
the South. He believed in democracy, which was probably why he supported 
the Americans helping out the South (or creating the South as a proxy state 
to contain communism, whichever explanation floats your boat).
comments.author: Rin la Harlequin

comments.text:
@tianba ưang: This is exactly what I am talking about here when it comes to 
discuss about whether of whom the territory water belongs to. I am sorry 
but I have to say that you need to google "historical facts" before go on 
to argue with me on this. Vietnam is an independent nation and we are in no 
mean related to China for a very long time. Just like Korea and Japan that 
we were, for a long time, influenced by the Chinese culture considering the 
fact that China has the longest history in the East side of this world. 
However, we got our independence long time ago so as Korea and Japan. The 
fac that you're saying "Chinese governement even open some facilities in 
Vietnam" is by no mean a true statement. Take a look at the world map and 
you will see Vietnam is regconized as an independent nation and we wont 
under any circumstances caused by ur aggressive Chinese government, ever 
give up our title, lands, and territory water belongs to us. As a matter of 
fact, we have evidences for everything we claim. On another note, you, me 
and many other people all know China is facing overpopulation and in need 
of solutions to resolve this problem, but going around threatening

comments.text:
I just want to say that this story made me realize how much pain my 
grandparents went through when they were younger. They are North Korean and 
escaped North Korea when the civil war started. They talk about the 
horrible dead bodies they've seen and the hunger they faced everyday on 
their journey to the south. They talk about how they survived by never 
giving up and having hope. I miss my grandpa who passed away 2 years ago. 
And I never got to thank him for his brave escape because that is the only 
reason I am alive today. So, grandpa, thank you for everything. And I miss 
you so much.﻿

comments.text:
Since your way of drawing inferences is on a totally different level , I 
will take the pain of breaking it down for ya ...

1. I sympathesize with the people of NK. And I think SK is an awesome 
country - it's a democracy , with wonderful people who enjoy freedom. So , 
I love/sympathesize the Koreans , not hate them.

2. I think Communism , fueled by China nad Russia, is the prime reason of 
NK's current state. And hence I despise their Govt's  , and if the people 
also support their actions in the case of NK , I would despise them as well.

3. I came to express myself , as I am used to , living in a democracy . 
People who are not used to freedom , and are blindly nationalistic , might 
not like my thought processes ,and take it as insult.
As for Pakistan , I have stated that it is a terrorist state, which is true 
to the core. It is primarily governed by it's military , and it's jehadist 
agenda.
As for China , I admire it's hard-working spirit and resolve , which 
eenabled it to adopt one-child policy in such a huge country ; but I 
despise it for it's bulliness. 

4. China is considered as a bully , not India. China , not India has a 
problem will all it's neighbours in SE Asia. India definitely has problems 
with Pakistan, which is unavoidable as it is a huge Islamic Jehadist Threat 
to the entire world , and hilariously with China as well. China is more 
than 3 times the size of India. Wonder why it needs any more land, and it's 
not that they are oil-fields where the disputes are.

5. India was a great ancient nation . But it isn't now. Somewhere in the 
mid-ages , India lost it's way in caste and creed business. But , India has 
fought against these , and these social dogma's are fast fast disappearing. 
It's not caste and creed , but dirty Indian politics that try to use them , 
that are the shackes of India's growth and prosperity.

6. India is not a feudal country . When the Constitution of India was being 
formed ,during the days of it's Independence , all types of feudalism was 
abolished. The landlords , kings , nawabs , etc. were stripped of their 
powers , and their powers merely remained to their inherited economic 
strength.
comments.author: Rajib Sharma

...... "I am a fool brainwashed by western media" -- This is western media

..... I understand u r a nationalist . So am I , and most people. That

comments.text:
Dude , South Korea had almost won the war against NK in the 1950's . China 
joined the war , and then restored back NK. Otherwise Korea would be one
